title: Will local elections be held in the city of Donetsk before 1 May 2016?
possible_answers: Yes, and the elections will be recognized by the government of Ukraine
Yes, but the elections will not be recognized by the government in Ukraine
preds: Just updating for passage of time.

NATO-RUSSIA MEETING DELAYS Elections past  IFP date  Although the meeting was unproductive, its occurrence is still notable. Russia has shown signs in recent days, particularly when it comes to Ukraine, that it is willing to compromise. On Tuesday, representatives from the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics, the separatist territories that Russia backs in eastern Ukraine, announced that they would postpone their local elections, scheduled for this week, until July 24. Ostensibly, the delay will allow more time for negotiations. The West and the Ukrainian government in Kiev have both maintained that elections should wait until necessary security components of the Minsk peace agreement have been implemented. Russia undoubtedly encouraged — if not demanded — the delay. ( behind pay wall) all rights reserved (c) 2016 Stratfor
https://www.stratfor.com/geopolitical-diary/russias-carrot-and-stick-strategy?utm_source=paidlist-a&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=*|DATE:|*&utm_content=Daily+Intelligence+Brief%3A+April+21%2C+2016

Zakharchenko signed a decree moving the election date to July 24.

No, I don't believe that local elections will be held in the city of Donetsk before May 1st. I believe this because not enough government officials in Ukraine respect international election standards, therefore, they will continue to postpone the election until they are ready.

With Ukraine's prime minister's resignation, now would be definitely good time to hold elections - however there aren't really sources supporting that option (then again, I googled only in english and czech, there may be something in russian)...
Wont reflect it in my prediction though because I was for a long time (a bit) higher on NOREC than the consensus , and I prefer minimizing loses to maximizing gains

Update and validate forecast in some areas. Some of my recent rationale yesterday as to why Russia prefers to allow Ukraine to take responsibility of not implementing election in Donetsk, questioning Ukraine's effort in doing not so, pressuring the dysfunctional government  "If they have a Donetsk election during the Ukraine political transition, Russia perhaps is accused of a coup and given reasons by opponents to impose sanctions. Instead Russian could say there is no one in Ukraine to negotiate a mutual understanding of a transition in the Minsk Agreement and say they are losing patience with the Ukraine government, adding more pressure to the Kiev leadership in domestic and international discussion of how they cannot settle their policy affairs." Update: Lavrov: Implementation of Minsk-2 stalled by non-fulfillment of political part by Kiev
http://tass.ru/en/politics/868692
The implementation of the Minsk Agreements is stalled by non-fulfillment by political part of the agreements by Kiev, Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov told a press conference on Monday after talks with his Swiss counterpart Didier Burkhalter.
"If the situation developed in the framework of implementing the roadmap [developed by Switzerland’s foreign minister], maybe political aspects of reforms as well, which now hamper the implementation of the Minsk Agreements because Ukrainian government is not yet ready to make relevant steps, maybe everything would have gone differently," Lavrov said.
Moscow is waiting for capable Contact Group and "Normandy format" partners to emerge in Kiev, Sergey Lavrov said on Monday answering a TASS question.
"Talking about the resignation of [Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseniy] Yatsenyuk and whether it may change anything in relation Kiev’s implementation of the Minsk Agreements, we are, of course, waiting for capable partners in the Contact group and in the ‘Normandy format’ to emerge. We see how everyone is absorbed by internal intrigues in Ukraine," he added.

Because even an elected government wouldn’t have any power as countries such as the US don’t recognize Donetsk as it’s own country, an elected government wouldn’t have much power. Despite this, there is a chance that elections are held anyway.

There is a 15% chance that local elections will be held in Donetsk, Ukraine before May 1, 2016; however a 1% chance that these elections will be recognized by other countries. This city has a large population of Pro-Russian citizens and is filled with rebels called coeptis who want Ukraine to return to Russia. Additionally, this city is viewed as a terrorist organization and is not recognized by all countries except Russia as a new country; therefore, other countries will not acknowledge the elections. Due to the close proximity to Russia and its influence, Donetsk, Ukraine will not hold local elections before May 1, 2016.

It seems like the popular opinion in Ukraine is towards holding elections, regardless of whether they are recognized by Ukraine or not. However, it is difficult for Donetsk to organize the resources to hold elections before May.

"Russia’s envoy to the Contact Group Boris Gryzlov hopes for consistent work on the law on election in Donbass and holding the vote in June despite the unsuccessful attempt to coordinate the date in Paris. "The efforts of the Contact Group in the first half of 2016 should be focused on preparing a special law on holding local election in Donbass, as well as organizing an election campaign in the aforementioned timeframe," Gryzlov said" More:
http://tass.ru/en/world/864407

Most likely elections will be held at some point, but it is highly unlikely that they will be held before May and it is also unlikely they will be acknowledged by other countries as legitimate Even Russian officials who are for the creation of a new pro-Russian government have doubts that these elections will happen anytime soon.

A lot of Ukraine wanted to go away from Russia and become part of the western technology unit. The Russian separatists in Donetsk rioted and separated from Ukraine. I give it a 5% chance because they are such a new country that they will not be recognized as a separate country for a long time.

The citizens in Donetsk decided that they wanted to be able to make decisions for themselves because they intend to split from Ukraine and go over to Russia. Because they believe that the sooner these elections take place the sooner Donetsk will be recognized as a separate entity and thus be able to split from the Ukraine, they are pushing these elections hard. However, Russia, who was the only country backing these elections, put out a statement claiming that they don’t think these elections will happen, implying a very low likelihood of these occurring before May 1. If these elections do end up happening, there is barely any chance that they will be recognized by other governments as the only countries to recognize Donetsk as a separate state are Russia and the Ukraine itself (who view them as a terrorist state and thus wouldn’t back these elections).

http://tass.ru/en/world/864407 "The Contact Group on the settlement of situation in Ukraine will hold another meeting today. It will take place against the backdrop of unresolved political crisis in the country and negotiations on election in Donbass that stalled after the Paris meeting of the "Normandy Quartet." At the ministerial meeting in the "Normandy format" on March 3 in the French capital, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Pavel Klimkin did not agree with the proposal supported by other foreign ministers to hold election in Donbass in June 2016. . . .  "Shellings continue in the zone of conflict. The sides have been recently accusing each other of covert preparation for a military offensive which threatens the whole peace process. Representatives of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic (DPR) are also concerned with the movement of Ukrainian forces to the so-called "grey zone" that was formed along the contact line after the sides withdrew heavy weaponry.
. . . 
"DPR’s envoy to the Contact Group Denis Pushilin said last week. "I don’t think that any serious agreements will be reached at the meeting (on March 23) but the process should continue," he added.
. . . 
"According to sources close to talks, the first-ever joint meeting of sub-groups on security and political issues is planned in Minsk for today. "The topic for discussion is ensuring security of holding election," the source told Lugansk Inform Center. The participants in the ministerial meeting of the "Normandy Quartet" in Paris put forward the task to prepare and submit to the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) until March 31 proposals on ensuring security at election. "Russia’s envoy to the Contact Group Boris Gryzlov hopes for consistent work on the law on election in Donbass and holding the vote in June despite the unsuccessful attempt to coordinate the date in Paris. "The efforts of the Contact Group in the first half of 2016 should be focused on preparing a special law on holding local election in Donbass, as well as organizing an election campaign in the aforementioned timeframe," Gryzlov said. "The law on local election should be coordinated by Kiev and Donbass with mediation of Russia and OSCE," he added. "Gryzlov also noted that several politicians in Ukraine that are directly involved in the negotiations process and holding election, publicly state that Kiev will not organize local election neither in 2016 nor in 2017. They say that from five to 25 years is required for holding local election in Donbass. "By doing this, Kiev openly demonstrates its reluctance to implement not only the Package of measures but also the agreements reached in the ‘Normandy format’," the Russian envoy said. "At today’s meeting in Minsk, DPR representatives also plan to raise an issue of continuing shellings by Ukrainian forces of the Donetsk filtration plant that supplies water not only part of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic (cities of Donetsk and Yasinovataya, villages of Vasilyevka and Spartak) but also several settlements controlled by Kiev (towns of Avdeyevka, Krasnogorovka and Verkhnetoretskoye).
. . . .
"Local election in Donbass is one of the key points of the political settlement in Ukraine’s east. According to the Minsk Agreements, it should have taken place back in 2015, simultaneously with a constitutional reform in Ukraine supposed to grant special status to separate parts of the Donetsk and Lugansk regions. However, dates were repeatedly postponed for adopting a law on special status and coordinating a law on local election due to Kiev’s reluctance to fulfill its commitments in the framework of the Minsk accords. "At the end of 2015, the leaders of the "Normandy Quartet" set a new deadline - first half of 2016. However, Ukraine still refuses to discuss preparations for election citing security concerns in the region and demanding to return control over the Russian-Ukrainian border which should be done after the election.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Best case/earliest scenario for these elections sounds to be June.  Most likely, however, they will be significantly later due to the continued low-level warring going on.

Going all in. Lots of great links. Extending on my previous forecast logic. Passage of time.

Factors to determine the probability of elections in Donetsk by May 1:
•	Russian Support
•	Donetsk militias gain substantial military advantage.
•	Negotiated settlement of hostilities To determine the probability of negotiating a between militants in Donbas and the government of Ukraine, we need to look at the  groups willingness to negotiate. Examining how these groups have behaved with regard to negotiation in the past and now. Some factors include: military success Eastern Ukraine, economic strength at home, political strength at home, political influence abroad and economic influence abroad. Each of these counted as 1 point.  My model multiplies the number of points for each actor times .2 to determine the willingness to negotiate (taking into consideration whether strength or weakness makes an actor more or less willing to negotiate).  Last I averaged the pro-Donbas scores (giving their average a weight of 2) and averaged the anti-Donbas scores (with a weight of 1), and then divided by 3. This then gave me an estimated probability of a negotiated agreement in Ukraine.
But then I took the statistic that 25% of all civil wars end in negotiation as my Bayesian prior. This lowers my prediction to 20%. I take this as an estimate for a year, making the probability per month 1.6. Since two months remain in the question, this gives a 3% chance of a negotiated settlement occurring.  I took this as a base, and added in the fact that Leader of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic in eastern Ukraine Alexander Zakharchenko said in February that he did not expect local elections in the DPR until 2017.  I thus decreased the possibility to 2%, leaving open a small amount of probability for the unforeseen.

The Ukrainian population does not want the region to secede, and it is unlikely that the election will be held under perfect conditions, so the Ukrainian government is likely to look for reasons why any election organized before May 1 is illegitimate.

The separatists have scheduled elections for April 20th, not February, I believe.   However, Kyiv has not shown a lot of interest in reaching an accommodation on elections for fear these might legitimize Russia's presence there.  There are also the issues of fairness and transparency of the voting process (see also: Crimea) as well as whether pro-Ukranian candidates would be allowed to openly participate and campaign.  Hard to see a Ukranian-recognized election happening there by April, and if the separatists hold their own elections on April 20th, it could restart fighting.  On the other hand, if oil keeps crashing and the Rouble keeps tanking,  maybe some of the pro-Russian residents there might opt to tie themselves closer to Ukraine and the EU once again!

Ukraine won't recognize elections with russian troops being present (and a withdrawal is unlikely). Therefore most likely no election (status quo ante) with a slim chance of one being held but not recognized by anyone outside Russia and eastern Ukraine.

There were reports that heavy Russian backed artillery in white was making its way to Donetsk, possibly to then divide into different eastern regions (The Interpreter, 2016) . Prior to that report, Ukraine claims they saw the highest number of attacks recorded since August, 2015 (Ibid).  The Ukraine government is becoming more divided and dysfunctional, causing doubt as to whether the agreements it made with Russia will continue after an inevitable shake up of leadership in the administration (Doff, 2016).  A weak and divided government works as much to Russia's goals as a Russian  backed Ukraine. The corruption has not disappeared in the Western backed Ukraine government, further preventing Ukraine from becoming a central and effective  authority ("Ambassador: France supports Ukraine, but will not hide truth," 2016). They are 130 of 168 in the corruption index, next to Russia (Transparency International, n.d.). Ukraine is becoming less an issue and more a financial and resource burden (Doff, 2016) for Europe whose attention has moved to the refugees, and terrorism. 
If there is no election due to uncertainty and instability, the worst case scenario within reason is a censure of Russia by the West and a sanction and a promise to have an election when the area is secure to do so in the non-NATO and non-EU country. A non-vote gives Russia more leverage in a region that will vote for Russia or is militarily superior army in Donetsk.   A pre-mature vote and a victory gives Russia nothing else to leverage and a green light for Western Ukraine to become by default a more Western ally. As in the case of Iran and the Russian built nuclear plant which took almost 20 years to build (World Nuclear News, 2014), delaying the goal gives Russia leverage than if they complete a Ukraine agreement. Falls the Shadow There are light military skirmishes in the disputed East areas and the political disagreements, or horse trading, continues between Kiev and Moscow and the pro-Russian factions.  Ukrainian members of the Minsk Trilateral group believe the Steinmeier Forumula is 'unrealistic.'  Alexander Zakharchenko says that no Ukrainian parties are permitted in the Donbas elections. President Poroshenko wants a return of prisoners, a pullback of Russians and weapons, a resolution on displaced persons, and a ceasefire.  However, if the Russians agree to follow the Minsk Agreement in following the norm of the Ukraine elections, then Russia could equally have access to a questionable and corrupt election strategy in Donbas.  These are long ,dragging, expectations from all parties and as these demands become a  lengthened stalemate; it becomes an elephant in the room. It becomes an elephant in the room for Europe which cannot complete a plan for Ukraine without thinking, but what of the East, how does that effect the EU's strategic and commercial agreements with Kyiv and Russia? The Ukraine economy is slowing and loans are due and the conflict in the East is both reducing funds and resources for the EU, Ukraine, Russia and the global banks.  This is more of a discussion between the US and Russia than with the EU. I do not think that Ukraine is a high priority for the US as it would rather Russia turn its attention to Ukraine and spend its resources and funding on that conflict, the way Russia involved itself in forcing the US to turn more attention and resources in the conflicts it had in Afghanistan and Iraq when backing Iran and other US opponents in the wars. In other words, payback is fair play. But Russia believes it needs Ukraine as a buffer whereas the EU has less a need for them as a strategic defense in the Northern European plain.  For Russia, it goes beyond  political support.  However, this stasis conflict could also work for Russia's advantage in breakaway and factional areas such as Transdneister or Moldova or South Ossetia where any perceived provocation against Russia in Ukraine could have repercussions in the spring within and beyond the Ukrainian disputed region.  As long as Russia hangs the Eastern disputed region out to dry, the non-NATO Ukraine hangs in the shadow with it. In realpolitik terms, the conflict in Ukraine really is between the United States and Russia - the Ukrainian government cannot afford to ignore what the United States "requests" - similarly, the self-appointed officials in Donetsk and Lugansk cannot ignore what Moscow demands.  As @dominich points out, this article: http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/news/article/russia-pushing-for-an-endgame-in-ukraine/556437.html makes clear that Moscow is definitely positioning to end the conflict. This means that Moscow will NOT allow the conflict-regions to hold elections because "elections could have derailed efforts, redoubled in recent weeks, to forge a lasting settlement to the...conflict" http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/67a5bc68-6c3e-11e5-aca9-d87542bf8673.html#axzz3xwphCEhZ (slightly dated, yes - argument is still 100% valid, however). 
The rebels will do nothing without Russia's go-ahead. Certainly not elections. This rules out holding elections that Ukraine will not recognize (thus, the 0% chance given to the NOREC option).  It therefore comes down to how quickly negotiations will take place. Right now, they're "stalled"
http://sputniknews.com/europe/20160122/1033528400/ukraine-contact-group-results.html . Moscow's terms are for Ukraine to have a permanent (not transitional) constitution that gives the breakaway regions autonomy. Until this is done, Russia will not give the border to Ukraine and the conflict will not conclude http://sputniknews.com/europe/20160120/1033449198/donbass-border-kuchma.html . If this is the case (and it may be the case), then the conflict will become "frozen" (like in Ossetia, Abkhazia and Transnistria). Elections may eventually take place, but not soon (and not within the time-frame specified by the question).  If the negotiations between Russia and the US are genuine (as seems to be the case), then the United States will have to put enough pressure on an unruly Kievan government to install a permanent constitution with autonomy clauses that appease Russia. Russia will then want to see 
1. The constitution implemented
2. Troops withdrawn (which still hasn't happened: shelling seems to be contiuing to the present time http://tass.ru/en/world/850716 - yes, I'm aware this is a Russian source)
3. A hand-over period  While all these things could be done before May 1st, it would be quite a lot to accomplish in the span of 3 months and the conflict has already dragged on for 2 years.  In short: I believe that either 
1. Elections will not take place within the given span of time 
2. Russia and America hussle really hard and put a lot of pressure on Kiev to finally acquiesce  The first of these seems the most likely, thus gaining the 70% probability.

This has some interesting perspective, and I think some persuasive points that Russia, at least, is looking to come to an endgame in the Donbass. http://www.themoscowtimes.com/article/556437.html The appointment of Surkov - who was the principal ideologist of United Russia in the 2000s as it became the ruling party - and the inventor of the notion of "sovereign democracy", and a very close ally of Putin who has also had responsibilities concerning Abkhazia and South Ossetia - to a role concerning the Donbass -  is particularly noteworthy.And that of Boris Gryzlov - a senior United Russia official, and long term Duma Chairman - is too. These are really big names for Russia to drop into the conflict. This *might* increase the chance of organizing elections in Donetsk - past experience (in Crimea, as well as in occupied Donetsk and Luhansk) has shown that elections (that lack full democratic scrutiny or process) can be organized fairly quickly - moreover, the elections to the "parliaments" of the two "people's republics" in Donetsk and Luhansk held in late 2014 did not involve the participation of "traditional" or pre-existing parties, only rather more nebulous factions. (This approach has also been seen, to various degrees, in other Russian-sponsored statelets - notably Transnistria, and to an extent Abkhazia.), so there can be expected to be much informality in practice. The question of whether Ukraine might implement the constitutional changes required under Minsk II, which would provide a structure by which any elections might be recognized by the Kyiv authorities (as discussed in my previous comment) remains unanswered. But I think these moves on Russia's part slightly increase the chance that some sort of elections will be held.

Russia is not too happy with much of world to its West, so it would not be surprising if the elections were held. They would definitely not be recognized by Ukraine (much less the rest of of the international community minus China). But at the same time, the elections may be pushed back at the last minute due to "continued negotiations" about the region with all the players.

Not entirely certain why Ukraine Parliament is stalling on passing the Constitutional amendment (vote 28 January). To prolong the embargo on Russia? I wouldn't put much faith in that plan working. If the EU sees Ukraine as the impediment to Minsk II implementation, many may decide to soften the embargo anyway. Russia has said it won't hold off on elections in Donbass beyond March. It's in Russia's interest for Donbass to hold elections, per Minsk II, so no one can say the impasse is Russia's fault. Russia has influence in Donbass, so it's very likely that elections will be held, with or without Ukraine's decentralization amendment. Will have to check back on 28 January. If the Constitutional amendment passes, it will mean that Ukraine has decided to implement Minsk II, so they will probably recognize the elections. That's the most sense I can make of the situation, in any case.

Reaffirming previous forecast.  One factor that influences the resolution here (and above all whether any elections in Donetsk would be recognized by by the Government in Kyiv) concerns  the need to implement constitutional changes providing for "decentralization" of Ukraine (and as such putting potentially Kyiv-aligned administrative bodies in the Donbass onto a formal legal framework) in accordance with the Minsk II agreement.  As stated at http://www.odessatalk.com/2016/01/constitutional-vote-fails-come-back-next-year-ukraine/  these changes should be implemented by the end of January 2016, and a parliamentary vote on them has been set for 28 Jan. The article also cites an article in the Ukrainian Constitution prohibiting the resubmission of legislation that has failed to be approved for the subsequent period of one year. In practice (as seen in previous attempts to amend the Ukrainian constitution, especially towards the end of the term of office of Pres Kuchma in 2002-04) there are ways to fudge this (e.g. by rival but similar submissions); while the Constitutional Court has often proven to be highly politicized and effectively to follow the will of the government of the day (eg almost instantaneous 2010 reversion to the pre-2004 version of the Constitution, providing for enhanced presidential powers; and indeed the similar 2014 reversion to the 2006-2010 version that weakened presidential powers...)   That said, the fact that powers are currently dispersed may be expected to inhibit such a top-down approach, unless the current President or Government are inclined to push this through. As yet, that seems uncertain or even unlikely.

It is not difficult to stage elections in territory your military occupies effectively, especially if they are only for domestic political consumption in your home country and you don't care what anybody else thinks about them.   Unsolicited and perhaps irrelevant bonus pontification:  The mock election scam is probably particularly tempting if public opinion in your home country is desperately looking for any signs of legitimacy in anything you've done lately, since clearly that's all they're going to get. It's a poor substitute for a functioning political and economic system, but you can probably get enough folks to grasp at it to keep you out of Big Trouble for a while longer.
